Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Student Debt and Family Relationships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This project examines the effect of student debt on the family relationships in the period of emerging adulthood after college and how families negotiate issues around student debt. This project asks two questions: (1) How does student debt shape family relationships in the period of emerging adulthood after college? (2) How do families manage the experience of indebtedness and repayment together? Data collection will be through two interviews 12 months apart with recent students, a monthly diary survey over the course of the year for these recent students, and an interview with their parents. Findings will be relevant to debates regarding reform of the US higher education financing system and access to and persistence in higher education.<br/><br/>The data consist primarily of interviews with about 100 recent college leavers and their parents. The young adult interviewees are recent attendees at two colleges that primarily serve in-state populations and include non-completers, first-generation students, and students with different majors. Interview topics are college life and parental support in college; the debt repayment situation; relationships between parents and young adult children, particularly as they relate to money and financial support; adult transitions; current orientation to debt; the role of salient other family members, particularly siblings; and what, if anything, parents and young adults feel they might owe each other now or in the future. Young adult respondents are interviewed twice. Between interviews, they are invited to participate in short, monthly surveys that anchor follow-up interviews and allow for the analysis of changing relationships and financial situations over time.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This doctoral dissertation research investigated how recent college attendees manage student debt, and how family relationships influence both debt and the recent students' transitions out of college. Support from the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant allowed the co-PI to conduct interviews and collect repeated survey data from recent college attendees on their debt repayment and the supports (both financial and otherwise) that they exchanged with their families. These data informed the co-PI's doctoral dissertation, titled "Student Debt and Higher Education Pathways".  The analyses in the dissertation examined the consequences of debt and family support for higher education and post-college life. 

In particular, the dissertation had several key findings. First, siblings emerged as a key element shaping the nature of family support that students received. Older siblings emerged as key resources helping younger siblings navigate college applications, financial aid, and higher education finance, particularly for first-generation and low-income students. Older siblings also had the potential to modify the availability of support from parents for younger siblings based on the outcome of the older sibling's higher education investment. Second, although student debt was a key factor that recent college graduates considered in deciding whether to attend graduate school, efforts to overcome this barrier were highly stratified, with higher-income graduates more likely to be able to rely on family supports to pay down debt, and lower-income graduates typically resorting to rhetorically recasting their debt as relatively small and manageable. Taken together, the research has implications for higher education finance policy as well as efforts to broaden access to higher education at all levels.
